conclusion: To determine if the difference in displacement between the two objects is necessarily continuously increasing during the time interval from 0 to t1, we need to analyze the given velocity-time (v-t) graph.
The area under the velocity-time graph represents the displacement of an object.
For object A, the displacement at any time t is given by the area under curve A up to that time.
For object B, the displacement at any time t is given by the area under curve B up to that time.
At t = 0, both objects start from rest, so their initial displacements are zero.

premise: As time progresses, the displacement of each object increases as the area under their respective curves accumulates.
conclusion: The displacement of each object increases over time.

premise: The difference in displacement between the two objects at any time t is the difference in the areas under the two curves up to that time.
conclusion: Let DA(t) be the displacement of object A at time t. Let DB(t) be the displacement of object B at time t. The difference in displacement is ΔD(t) = DA(t) - DB(t).
From the graph, we observe that curve A is always above curve B for the entire time interval from 0 to t1.

premise: Since DA(t) > DB(t) for all t in the interval [0, t1], it follows that ΔD(t) = DA(t) - DB(t) > 0 for all t in this interval.
conclusion: The difference in displacement ΔD(t) is positive for all t in the interval [0, t1].

premise: The difference in displacement ΔD(t) is a continuous function because both DA(t) and DB(t) are continuous functions (as they are integrals of continuous velocity functions).
Since ΔD(t) is positive and continuous, it cannot decrease or become zero within the interval [0, t1].
conclusion: The difference in displacement between the two objects is necessarily continuously increasing during the time interval from 0 to t1.
